revolt.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a refusal to accept someone’s authority or obey rules or laws
revolt.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The prime minister is now facing a revolt by members of his own party.
a revolt over the proposed spending cuts
French farmers are in revolt over cheap imports.
revolt.translation[0].definitions[1].def: strong and often violent action by a lot of people against their ruler or government
revolt.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Troops loyal to the president crushed the revolt.
a revolt against the central government
the successful revolt of the American colonies
revolt.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 2: strong and often violent action by a lot of people against their ruler or government
revolt.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: In 1821 revolts broke out in Moldavia and Wallachia.
At a word from Gandhi, India would have risen in revolt.

The Russians speedily crushed the revolt.
This was the best-known peasant revolt in Soviet history.

Somalis living just across the Ethiopian border rose up in armed revolt.
revolt.translation[1].definitions[0].def: if people revolt, they take strong and often violent action against the government, usually with the aim of taking power away from them
revolt.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: It was feared that the army would revolt against the government.
revolt.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to refuse to accept someone’s authority or obey rules or laws
revolt.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Some members of the government may revolt against this proposed legislation.
revolt.translation[1].definitions[2].def: if something revolts you, it is so unpleasant that it makes you feel sick and shocked
revolt.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: He was revolted by the smell.
revolt.translation[1].definitions[2].not: Revolt is usually passive in this meaning
